In this problem, we will discuss the relationship between the value of an annuity and the interest rate. 

Additionally, we will determine the effect of a sudden rate decrease to 5% and a rise of 15% in the value of our investment if the annual payment is $8,500 for 11 years with an interest rate of 10%.

For the first requirement, let's explain the relationship between the value of an annuity and the interest rate.

The relationship between the interest rate and the value of an annuity is inversely proportional. The interest rate directly affects the value of an annuity, increasing its value as the interest rate increases and vise versa.

We will determine the impact of the sudden increase and decrease of a rate in our investment for the following requirement. 

First, determine the present value of the investment at the initial rate of 10%; we will consider the following details:

| Particulars |            |
|-------------|------------|
| Cash amount | $8,500     |
| Rate        | 10%        |
| Period      | 11 (years) |

To determine the present value of the investment, we will use the present value of an annuity formula. The formula of the annuity present value is as follows:

$$ \begin{aligned}
\text{Present Value of an Annuity} &=C\times\dfrac{1-\dfrac{1}{\left(1+r\right)^t}}{r}
\end{aligned}$$

Where:

$C$, which represent the cash amount\
$r$, which refers to the rate\
$t$, which symbolizes the period

To summarized, the relationship of between the value of an annuity and the interest rate is inversely proportional hence, if the rate drops to 5% the value of our investment increases to $70,604.52 and, if the rate increases to 15% the investment value decreases to  $44,486.55.
